aero.name: Governance Foundation
aero.about: When reviewing any codebase, the first step is understanding the governance model, if it exists. This determines whether permissioned functions and elevated privileges are ultimately controlled by tokenholders.

criteria.name: On-chain Workflow Control
criteria.about: Does an on-chain workflow exist that gives holders ultimate voting power? (e.g., Timelocks or DAOs).
criteria.notes:
AERO holders lock AERO in VotingEscrow to receive veAERO represented as veNFTs. veAERO holders vote each epoch on gauge weights via the Voter contract. Based on the final vote distribution, the Minter mints weekly AERO emissions, which the Voter distributes to gauges proportionally to votes received.

An EmergencyCouncil exists to handle contingencies. It can be invoked to kill or revive gauges, update pool name and symbol metadata, and rotate the EmergencyCouncil itself.

criteria.name: Role Accountability
criteria.about: Are significant protocol roles accountable to tokenholders, even if delegated?
criteria.notes:
veAERO holders indirectly control AERO emissions through epoch-based gauge voting executed by the Voter and Minter.

An EmergencyCouncil exists which is not elected by veAERO holders. It holds limited emergency powers, including killing or reviving gauges and managing pool metadata. This role exists explicitly for crisis handling and sits outside direct tokenholder election.

criteria.name: Governance Concentration
criteria.about: Does any one group control a majority share of the voting supply?
criteria.notes: Distribution of AERO and veAERO voting power outside of the core team has not been independently verified.

aero.name: Metric 1: Token Control (On-chain)
aero.about: Token ownership and protocol ownership are separate questions and must be analysed independently. The core question here is straightforward: can a third party meaningfully interfere with ownership of the token?

criteria.name: Upgrade Sovereignty
criteria.about: Do holders control the upgrade logic via governance, or is the contract immutable?
criteria.notes: The AERO token contract is immutable and does not use a proxy pattern. The Minter contract, which is authorized to mint AERO, is also non-upgradeable.

criteria.name: Supply Sovereignty
criteria.about: Is the supply fixed/programmatic, or do holders control the minting process?
criteria.notes:
AERO minting is fully programmatic and epoch-based (1 epoch = 1 week), enforced by the non-upgradeable Minter contract.

During the first 14 epochs, emissions increased by 3% per epoch. After epoch 14, emissions decay by 1% per epoch. After approximately epoch 67, when emissions fall below 9M AERO per epoch, minting switches to a tail emission model governed by `tailEmissionRate`, initially set to 0.67%. veAERO holders can adjust this rate by ±0.01% per epoch or leave it unchanged.

In addition to weekly gauge emissions, the protocol separately mints growth emissions for veAERO holders using the formula:
`weeklyEmissions × (1 − veAERO.totalSupply / AERO.totalSupply)² × 0.5`. This creates a counter-cyclical incentive where veAERO rewards decrease as more AERO is locked and increase when less AERO is locked.

A team emission rate also exists and is currently set to 0% of total weekly emissions.

criteria.name: Censorship Immunity
criteria.about: Are there no guardian or admin roles capable of freezing, blacklisting, or seizing tokens?
criteria.notes:
The AERO token has no blacklist, pause, or seizure mechanisms. 

 **Team Rate:** the team rate (share of weekly emissions allocated to the team) can be modified by a Gnosis Safe controlled by the Aerodrome team.

**Emission Rate:** Changes to the weekly emission rate (±0.01% or unchanged) are controlled by veAERO holders through governance.

evidence.name: Emission Rate Change By Governor set to different Gnosis Safe:

aero.name: Metric 2: Protocol Control (On-chain)
aero.about: Rather than analysing everything, we focus on what directly affects ownership and value.

criteria.name: Upgrade Sovereignty
criteria.about: Do holders control the implementation logic of the protocol?
criteria.notes: Core Aerodrome protocol contracts are non-upgradeable and do not use proxy patterns.

criteria.name: Gated Access Control
criteria.about: Are sensitive parameters gated by privileged roles?
criteria.notes:
**Non-SlipStream:** The fees are set on the PoolFactory which can be changed by the `feeManager` which is set to Gnosis Safe. 

 **SlipStream:** For CLPoolFactory, the fees are set inside the SwapFeeModule which allows feeManager to change fees (currently set as GnosisSafe)

evidence.name: SwapFeeModule: `setCustomFee` is allowed by CLFactory.swapFeeManager = GnosisSafe

aero.name: Metric 3: Value Accrual & Control (On-chain)
aero.about: Value accrual matters alongside token and protocol control.

criteria.name: Accrual Active
criteria.about: Are value flows active and governed by holders?
criteria.notes:
**Gauge Emissions:** veAERO holders vote on gauge weights each epoch. The Voter distributes weekly AERO emissions to gauges proportionally. Liquidity providers deposit LP tokens into gauges to earn emissions based on their share.

 **Growth Emissions:** veAERO holders receive the rewards from the growth emissions(see Supply section for more). These growth emissions are transferred to RewardDistributor and veAERO holders can claim it in proportion of their ve balance. .

**Trading Fees:** For non-slipstream pools, 100% of swap fees go to LPs staked in gauges.For slipstream (CL) pools, the swap fee is split - where some portion goes to the Gauge contract and the rest stays in a pool(claimable by LPs). The Gauge sends the fees  to the feesVotingReward contract. veAERO holders claim these fees on feesVotingReward. It’s worth noting only those veAERO holders that voted for the gauge receive these fees.

evidence.name: Gauge Deposit Logic(see `earned` function as well)

criteria.name: Treasury Ownership
criteria.about: Is the protocol treasury programmatically controlled by the token-governance workflow?
criteria.notes: There is no protocol treasury. All trading fees from swapping pools are distributed to veAERO holders and LPs.

criteria.name: Accrual Mechanism Control
criteria.about: Can holders modify accrual parameters (e.g., changing fee splits or rates)?
criteria.notes:
veAERO holders control: 

 **1:** the AERO rewards they receive by locking AERO tokens in VotingEscrow. 

 **2:** the AERO emissions going into gauges by voting for them in Voter

aero.name: Metric 4: IP & Distribution (Off-chain)
aero.about: Onchain ownership is only one half the story, in many cases. Distribution controls coordination. Even with immutable contracts, the ability to shift users to a fork or new deployment can break the link between existing tokenholders and future activity.

criteria.name: IP Ownership (Brand)
criteria.about: Is there evidence of DAO/holder ownership of trademarks, logos, and brand names?
criteria.notes: A U.S. trademark filing for "AERODROME" lists Perpetual Cyclist Services LLC (a Delaware for-profit company) as the applicant/owner. There is no public documentation indicating that the trademark is owned by the DAO or directly by tokenholders.

criteria.name: IP Ownership (NPD)
criteria.about: Do holders have legal rights to new product development (patents, trade secrets, proprietary codebase)?
criteria.notes: No tokenholder-representing legal entity is clearly documented. New product development appears to be coordinated through off-chain entities (labs/foundation), with governance influence exercised indirectly via on-chain mechanisms rather than explicit legal ownership rights.

criteria.name: Distribution (Website)
criteria.about: Does the DAO/token entity own the primary domain (rather than an individual or external entity)?
criteria.notes: The primary interface legal terms identify the Aerodrome Foundation as the contracting party. There is no public filing confirming that the domain or frontend infrastructure is legally owned or directly controlled by a tokenholder-governed entity.

criteria.name: Distribution (Socials)
criteria.about: Does the DAO have administrative control over primary channels (X, Discord, Telegram)?
criteria.notes: Public materials do not clearly document formal DAO-level administrative ownership of primary social or communication channels. Control appears to rest with the Foundation or associated operating entities rather than a legally defined tokenholder-controlled structure.
